The half-finished carpet on it depicted a famous battle from the valley’s history, a complex tapestry of horsemen and warriors. “It has been the same for a year,” Soraya added. “He has not touched it.” But Luna knew he had. He had been carding the wool. Not for the women’s workshop, but for his own secret work. The ledger wasn’t a book. It was the carpet. The map she had been looking for was not written in ink, but woven in thread, a secret history hidden in plain sight. “Soraya,” Luna said, her voice now sharp with a sudden, breathtaking certainty. “I need you to get me into that study.”The request was so audacious, so utterly insane, that for a moment Soraya’s fear was eclipsed by a wave of pure, incredulous fury. She lurched forward in the darkness, her hands finding the front of Luna’s tunic, her fingers twisting in the fabric. Her face was inches from Luna’s, her breath hot and ragged. “Are you mad?” she hissed, her voice a saw-toothed whisper of desperation. “The study is my grandfather’s heart. My brother guards it with his life. To enter it is to sign our own death warrants. I brought you food. I brought you water. I will not bring you my own execution.” Her grip was surprisingly strong, the desperate strength of a cornered animal.

Luna did not struggle. She remained perfectly still, a calm island in the storm of Soraya’s terror. She let the younger woman’s panic break against her like a wave, waiting for its energy to recede. “He is leaving,” Luna said, her voice soft but resonant, cutting through Soraya’s frantic whispers. “In two days, he goes to meet The Teacher. He will not be here to guard his heart. And your brother will go with him. They are the lock. And they are leaving the door.” She placed her hands gently over Soraya’s, not to pry them away, but to hold them, a gesture of profound and startling empathy. “This is not my choice, Soraya. It is yours. You can let them go, let them bind your family even deeper into this man’s service. You can watch your grandfather drown, as you said. Or you can help me find the one thing that might save him from the choice he is about to make.”

The simple act of touch, of shared stillness in the dark, seemed to drain the fight from Soraya’s body. Her hands slackened their grip, her shoulders slumped. The image Luna painted was too stark, too true. She had seen the life drain from her grandfather’s eyes over the past year, his pride replaced by a grim, joyless pragmatism. She had watched the art of her ancestors, a vibrant language of color and history, be perverted into the drab, functional uniform of a zealot. “What is it you think you will find?” she whispered, her fight replaced by a hollow, aching curiosity. “What is so important in that room?”

“A story,” Luna replied. “The one he is afraid to write down, so he weaves it instead. The names, the numbers, the locations… it is all there, hidden in the threads of that old battle scene. The story of his surrender. I need to read it.” Soraya pulled away, the contact broken, the cold reality of the room rushing back in. She stood for a long moment, a ghost of indecision in a tomb of failed projects. The choice was impossible, a sheer cliff on one side and a roaring fire on the other. But the fire was certain, and the cliff… the cliff held the barest possibility of a foothold. “Two days,” Soraya said, her voice flat and dead, the sound of a person accepting their own doom. “When they leave for the mountains, the house will be quiet. But the guards at the gate will remain. You will never get past them.”

“I won’t have to,” Luna said, a new, sharp energy in her voice. “The other woman, Samira. She will create a diversion. A fire. In the dye workshop. It must be at the hour of afternoon prayers, when the men are distracted and the sun is in the west. The fire will draw the guards from the gate. It will give us the time we need.” The plan was born in the darkness, a desperate, intricate piece of choreography relying on three unwilling partners, each performing their part in isolation. Soraya let out a sound that was half-sob, half-laugh. It was the sound of a mind breaking, or perhaps, the sound of one being forged into something new and hard. “A fire,” she repeated numbly. “You will burn my house down to save it.” Without another word, she unbarred the door and slipped out, leaving Luna alone in the darkness, the air now thick not with despair, but with the terrifying, electric potential of their plan.

The next day and a half was a silent, nerve-shredding exercise in controlled paranoia. Every normal interaction was layered with a secret, terrifying meaning. When Zara walked to the well, her path took her past the dye workshop, her eyes making a cold, swift inventory of the flammable materials: the piles of dry carded wool, the jugs of linseed oil used to treat the wooden looms, the stacks of firewood for heating the vats. She was no longer a laborer; she was an arsonist, planning her crime in plain sight. Her every movement was watched by Hamid, whose suspicion had not abated, but had settled into a kind of lazy, contemptuous vigilance. He was a predator content to watch his prey exhaust itself in its cage.

The communication came during the noon meal. Soraya, serving the women their plates of rice and stew, moved with a stiff, automaton-like precision. As she placed a plate before Zara, her hand brushed against Zara’s, and a small, hard object was pressed into her palm. It was a date pit, a common piece of after-meal refuse. Zara closed her hand around it, her face a mask of bland indifference, and continued eating. Later, alone behind the kitchens, she examined it. Scratched into its surface with the tip of a pin were two symbols: a crude drawing of a sun at its zenith, and a tiny, almost invisible flame. Afternoon prayers. The fire. The plan was on. Zara crushed the pit under the heel of her boot, obliterating the evidence, her mind already moving on, calculating the timing, the wind direction, the precise amount of accelerant needed to create a fire that was spectacular enough to cause panic, but controlled enough not to consume the entire compound.

On the morning of the second day, the compound stirred with the energy of departure. Babur and Hamid emerged from the main house dressed not as weavers, but as travelers, with heavy cloaks and sturdy boots. A palpable sense of relief and anxiety emanated from the women. The patriarch was leaving, a temporary lifting of his oppressive authority, but he was walking toward a different, more dangerous power. Soraya brought them a final cup of tea, her hands steady for the first time in days, her face a mask of serene, daughterly duty that was the most terrifying performance of all. As Babur mounted his horse, his gaze swept the courtyard, and for a moment, it rested on Zara. It was a long, measuring look, filled with a cold, weary knowledge. He knew she was more than she seemed. He knew he was leaving a viper in his nest. But his appointment in the mountains was unavoidable. He was a man caught between two threats, and he had chosen to face the one he understood better. With a final, grim nod to his remaining sons, he and Hamid rode out of the gate, their figures shrinking against the vast, indifferent backdrop of the mountains.

The hours that followed were the longest of Zara’s life. The afternoon sun beat down on the courtyard, baking the dust. The guards at the gate, freed from the direct supervision of Hamid, grew lax, talking and laughing amongst themselves. The workshop was quiet, the women working with a subdued, listless energy. Zara waited, every muscle in her body screaming for action. She watched the sun creep across the sky, a slow, merciless clock. When the first, faint call to afternoon prayers began to echo from the village mosque below, a sound that had become the background music to her captivity, it was now a starting pistol. She took a deep, steadying breath, the dry, hot air searing her lungs, and began to move.### Chapter 10

Zara moved with the unhurried deliberation of a farmer tending her fields. She ambled toward the dye workshop, a space now deserted as the men answered the call to prayer and the women rested in the midday heat. To any casual observer, she was simply Samira, fetching a tool or checking on a cooling vat. But inside her mind, a cold, precise clock was ticking down. She had chosen her spot with care: a corner where a stack of dry firewood was piled against a wooden support beam, and where several large piles of greasy, undyed wool lay like flammable clouds. Beside them sat a half-empty jug of linseed oil. It was a perfect confluence of fuel and opportunity.

She did not use a match or a lighter. Such items would be evidence. Instead, she knelt as if examining the base of the loom, her back to the courtyard. From a small pouch at her waist, she took out a shard of flint and a small piece of steel she had chipped from a broken shovel head. It was a primitive, laborious method, a weapon of last resort learned in a survival course she had once dismissed as theatrical. Now, it was the key. She struck the steel against the flint, her movements small, controlled, shielded by her body. Sparks flew, dying in the dust. Again. And again. The sound was a faint, rhythmic *click-click-click*, easily mistaken for an insect or a cooling piece of metal. Finally, a single, determined spark leaped onto a small nest of wool fluff she had prepared, catching with a tiny, hungry glow.

Zara gently blew on it, coaxing the ember from a pinprick of orange to a greedy, growing circle. It was alive. She added more fluff, then a handful of greasy wool. The wool did not burst into flame, but began to smolder, a thick, acrid smoke rising in a sluggish column. This was the first alarm. She gave it thirty seconds to build, then she uncorked the jug of linseed oil and poured a generous stream onto the smoldering pile and the adjacent firewood. The *whoosh* of the catching flame was a sudden, violent exhalation, a hungry beast unleashed. The fire did not rise cleanly; it was a churning, black-smoke belcher, the oil and lanolin-rich wool burning with a thick, suffocating stench that was utterly alien to the clean scents of the compound. Zara was already moving away, melting back into the shadows behind the kitchens before the first shout of alarm echoed across the courtyard. She found her new observation post, a narrow gap between a granary and the outer wall, and watched the chaos she had birthed.

The first to react were the two guards at the gate. They turned, their faces a mixture of confusion and alarm, and then began to run toward the billowing smoke. A moment later, men poured out of the small village mosque, their prayers abandoned. Shouts of “Fire!” and “Water!” created a cacophony of panicked commands. The fire, feeding on the dry wood and oil-soaked wool, was now a roaring bonfire, licking at the eaves of the workshop, the black smoke a pillar of disaster visible for miles. The diversion was a success, a spectacular, terrifying success.

The sound of the first shout was the signal that brought Soraya’s world into sharp, terrifying focus. She had been waiting in the shadows of the main house, her body a single, rigid knot of fear. At the sound of the alarm, she ran to the storeroom, her bare feet slapping against the cool stone floor. Her hands fumbled with the heavy wooden bar, her fingers clumsy with panic. She lifted it, pulled the heavy door open, and stared into the darkness where Luna had been imprisoned. "Now," she breathed, the word a ragged gasp. Luna emerged, her eyes blinking rapidly, adjusting from the absolute darkness to the hazy, smoke-filled light of the afternoon. She did not speak, but her gaze was sharp, her body coiled with a focused energy that stood in stark contrast to Soraya’s frantic terror. "This way," Soraya whispered, grabbing Luna’s arm and pulling her along.

They moved through the now-deserted corridors of the main house, their progress a mad dash through a maze of shadows and sudden shafts of light. The sounds of shouting and the crackle of flames from the courtyard were a constant, driving pulse, a soundtrack to their desperate gamble. Soraya led Luna to the heavy, carved door of her grandfather's study. It was unlocked. She pushed it open and shoved Luna inside, her eyes wide with a terror that bordered on madness. "Be quick," she hissed, her gaze darting back down the empty hallway. "Be quick, or we are both ghosts." She did not enter the room herself, but stood guard outside, a terrified, unwilling sentry, her body pressed against the wall, listening.

Luna stepped into the still, quiet heart of the storm. The study was exactly as she remembered it, a sanctuary of order and history untouched by the chaos raging just outside its walls. She ignored the books, the ledgers, the symbols of Babur’s legitimate authority. Her eyes went straight to the loom in the corner, and the magnificent, half-finished carpet hanging from its beams. It was a battle scene, a chaotic swirl of horsemen and foot soldiers locked in a desperate struggle, a historical moment of Panjshiri defiance frozen in thread. But as Luna drew closer, her eyes scanning the intricate patterns, she saw it was not just one story. It was two.

Woven into the ancient battle were subtle, almost invisible anomalies. The main threads were traditional vegetable dyes, their colors rich but muted. But here and there, a single thread in a warrior's cloak or a horse's trapping would be a slightly different shade, a black that was too deep, a red that was too uniform—the unmistakable purity of modern, synthetic dyes. They were flaws, deliberate and meaningful. And then she saw the main pattern. The battle was not a random melee. The positions of the key figures, the chieftains and heroes of the old war, corresponded with uncanny precision to the major towns and land features of the modern province. It was a map, a palimpsest of history and logistics.

Her eyes flew across the surface, her mind racing, translating the symbolic language. A chieftain on a white horse whose position corresponded with the town of Charikar had ten tiny, black knots tied into his horse's mane. Ten men. A stylized depiction of a mountain pass was woven with threads of an unnatural green. The location of the hidden weapons cache. A line of retreating archers near the edge of the tapestry, their quivers rendered with threads of a slightly different brown, pointed directly toward a remote tributary of the Panjshir River. A rendezvous point. It was all there—troop numbers, locations, supply routes—a secret war plan hidden within a celebration of a historic one. Babur had not surrendered; he had documented his enemy’s every move, creating an indelible record of their secrets, a final, desperate act of defiance disguised as collaboration.

Luna was so lost in the intricate narrative of the weave that she did not hear Soraya's sharp, indrawn breath from the hallway. Zara, from her hiding place, had seen it first. Karim, Babur’s second son, the one left in charge, was not with the others fighting the fire. He had stood for a long moment, watching the chaos, his face a mask of cold suspicion. Then, with a decisive movement, he had turned and begun walking with a quick, determined stride toward the main house. Zara had no way to communicate, no time. She ripped the small, polished metal mirror from her survival kit, angled it into the sun, and sent a desperate, flashing pulse of light toward the study’s window.

The flash of light on the far wall of the corridor was what made Soraya gasp. It was a starburst of pure panic. She burst into the study, her face ashen. "Someone is coming!" she cried, her voice a strangled whisper. "We have to go!" Luna was ripped from her concentration. She took one last, sweeping look at the tapestry, her mind a frantic camera, trying to burn the entire map into her memory. Soraya grabbed her arm, her nails digging into Luna's flesh, and pulled her from the room. They fled, Soraya leading her back not to the storeroom, but to the small, empty chamber that had been their assigned quarters. She shoved Luna inside. "Stay here. Do not move. Do not breathe," she commanded, her voice shaking, and pulled the door shut, leaving Luna in a room that was no longer a prison, but was far from a sanctuary. The plan was broken. The diversion had ended, and the hunt had just begun.The door of the small room closed, plunging Luna into a familiar, dusty twilight. But this time, it was not the suffocating darkness of a prison; it was the tense, temporary concealment of a hiding place. Through the thin wooden door, she could hear the chaos of the fire, a roaring, chaotic counterpoint to the thrumming silence in her own head. The map of the carpet was burned into her memory, a complex tapestry of names and locations that felt impossibly vast and fragile, a secret she had to carry out of this valley on her own two shoulders. Her body was a library, and the librarians were coming to burn it down. She heard the muffled, frantic exchange between Soraya and someone else—Karim—the voices a low, angry buzz that she could not decipher but whose terrified energy was perfectly clear.

Soraya’s performance was born of a terror so pure it became a kind of sublime art. She met Karim as he stormed out of the study, his face a thundercloud of suspicion. She did not cower. She held up a small, silver-inlaid box, an heirloom that held her mother’s meager jewelry. Her face was a mask of dutiful, panicked concern. “Karim!” she cried, her voice pitching just high enough to sound authentic. “The smoke, it is reaching this wing of the house! I was securing mother’s things. The fire is worse than they are saying.” She deliberately misinterpreted his rage, redirecting it from his search for a spy to his duty as the compound's protector. She made the fire his problem, his immediate failure, his responsibility. “The men at the gate are useless! They run around like headless chickens while the workshop burns!”

Karim’s suspicion was a physical thing, a pressure in the air between them, but his sister’s words were a sharp, undeniable hook. He was the man in charge. The fire was his shame. He looked from her wide, terrified eyes—which he read as fear of the flames—to the billowing smoke he could now see through a window at the end of the hall. He was torn between two duties, the hunt for the internal threat and the fight against the external one. The fire, however, was a public disaster, a visible challenge to his authority. The spy could wait. The fire could not. “Stay in the house,” he snarled, his fury now aimed at the incompetence of his men. “Keep the women away from the courtyard.” He pushed past her, his mind now consumed with buckets and water lines, the problem of the invisible enemy momentarily supplanted by the roar of the visible one.

From her hiding place between the granary and the wall, Zara watched the entire exchange unfold like a silent film. She saw Karim emerge, his rage redirected. She saw Soraya sag against the doorframe, her performance finished, her strength utterly spent. Zara knew this was not a victory, but a reprieve, a temporary stay of execution. As soon as the flames were out, the hunt would resume with a cold, renewed fury. The extraction window was not in a few hours; it was now, under the chaotic cover of the disaster she had created. She abandoned her post, moving with a fluid urgency she had not allowed herself until this moment. She was a wraith, skirting the edges of the chaos, her path taking her along the blind side of the main house, toward the one place her instincts screamed was the key: the high, barred window of Luna’s room.

Inside that room, Luna had come to the same conclusion. She was a liability where she was, a stationary target. The muffled voices had faded, but she knew her time was measured in the life of the fire outside. The door was not an option. Her eyes went to the window. It was a small, high rectangle of hazy, smoke-filled sky, at least twelve feet up the rough plaster wall, barred with two thick, rust-pitted iron rods. It was an impossible escape. And for a creature of the air, the impossible was merely a technical problem. She upended the flimsy wooden cot, its legs scraping loudly against the floor, a sound that made her freeze, listening. Hearing nothing but the distant roar, she propped it against the wall. It was a rickety, unstable launchpad, but it was a start.

What followed was a silent, desperate climb, a piece of vertical choreography that drew on every ounce of her training. She used the uneven texture of the adobe wall for microscopic handholds, her bare feet finding purchase where a boot would have found none. She launched herself from the shaking frame of the cot, her body a coiled spring of muscle, catching the lower edge of the window frame with her fingertips. For a moment she hung there, her muscles screaming, her body a pendulum against the wall. With a surge of strength born of pure adrenaline, she pulled herself up, hooking one leg over the sill. She was perched in the opening like a gargoyle, the sounds of the courtyard suddenly loud and clear below her. The iron bars were thick, set deep into the crumbling adobe. She wrapped her callused hands around one and pulled, not with a jerk, but with a steady, relentless pressure, her entire body a lever. The old mortar groaned, a fine powder raining down on her face. It was giving way.

Just as she felt the bar shift, a dark shape rose up on the other side of the opening. It was Zara. Her face was streaked with soot, her eyes wide and fierce. There was no time for relief, no space for words. Their eyes locked in a shared, desperate understanding. Zara gripped the bar from the outside, her own formidable strength joining Luna’s. Together, they pulled, a silent, synchronized act of will. With a grating shriek of protesting metal and crumbling earth, the bar tore loose from its upper mounting, bending outward just enough to create a narrow, body-sized gap. Zara reached through, not to help Luna, but to brace the wall, her hand a firm, solid anchor. “Come on, fly-girl,” she hissed, the words a rough prayer. Luna didn't hesitate. She twisted her body, contorting herself through the narrow opening in a movement that would have broken the bones of a normal person, and dropped silently to the ground beside her friend. She landed in a crouch, a ghost born from a high window, her feet finding the solid, unforgiving ground. They were together. They were outside the house. But they were still deep in the heart of the fire. The flames of the workshop cast long, dancing shadows, and in the chaos, two women prepared to become smoke.
